Netizen contribution
A heating company in Hegang said that due to the sharp rise in coal prices, it could not obtain government subsidies and the company had already lost 7 to 8 million yuan, so it would stop heating from the 5th.
It is reported that the current temperature in Heilongjiang is minus 20 degrees Celsius.

name: æè€å¸ˆä¸æ˜¯ä½ è€å¸ˆ
content:
It is actually very dangerous for the government to allow these people to spread rumors without any evidence.
Because this will not only not prevent the next public emergency (because public emergencies are not driven by rewards), but on the contrary it is likely to attract a group of people who think they can get money to join in.
So I sincerely say that this kind of rumor-mongering is more dangerous than spreading videos, and I suggest just arresting them.

name: æè€å¸ˆä¸æ˜¯ä½ è€å¸ˆ
content:
BBC News
As many countries strengthen quarantine measures for Chinese travelers, China says it will adopt the "reciprocity principle" to counter.
However, in fact, to this day, China is still implementing the world's strictest entry policy. Therefore, if the "reciprocity principle" is adopted to counter, it may refer to the entry 0+0 policy that was completely relaxed on January 8, that is, like airports in various countries, you can go home directly after taking nucleic acid tests.

name: æè€å¸ˆä¸æ˜¯ä½ è€å¸ˆ
content: Several Luyi local netizens submitted articles to me saying that the incident was caused by someone trying to set off firecrackers under a police car.

name: æè€å¸ˆä¸æ˜¯ä½ è€å¸ˆ
content: Another Twitter user said, "Hey, Mr. Li, you are whitewashing again. But I don't think so. After all, compared to the police arresting people and causing conflicts with the public, taking the initiative to blow up police cars with firecrackers is more in line with the overseas definition of "revolution". At present, there is indeed no more accurate information about the cause of the incident, and several netizens have submitted articles to me, so I will post it for the time being and let everyone judge for themselves.

content:
Recently, the term "äººçŸ¿" has become a hot topic on the Chinese Internet. At 8 o'clock this morning, it was even briefly on Weibo's hot search (now deleted).
The term "äººçŸ¿" first appeared in the People's Daily in 1984, meaning that people are a kind of "resource".
Today, it is more often used by netizens to ridicule themselves and metaphorically describe their personal destiny. The meaning is similar to "å±Œä¸" (a loser) and "ç‰›é©¬ (a cow and horse), that is, a life dominated by others, with no hope and meaning.
